Cards.Front: What are the four pillars of OOP?
Cards.Back: Encapsulation, Inheritance, Polymorphism, and Abstraction
A blueprint or template that defines the properties (fields) and behaviors (methods) of objects
An instance of a class - a concrete entity created from a class template with specific values
Bundling data and methods that work on that data within a class, and restricting direct access to some components
Keywords that control the visibility/accessibility of classes and members: public, private, protected, internal
The member is only accessible within the same class
The member is accessible from anywhere in the program
A mechanism where a new class (child/derived) inherits properties and methods from an existing class (parent/base)

Cards.Front: What is the 'base' keyword used for in C#?
Cards.Back: To access members of the base (parent) class from within a derived (child) class
The ability of objects of different types to be accessed through the same interface, with each type responding in its own way
When a derived class provides a different implementation of a method that is already defined in its base class

Cards.Front: What is the 'virtual' keyword used for?
Cards.Back: To allow a method in a base class to be overridden in derived classes

Cards.Front: What is the 'override' keyword used for?
Cards.Back: To provide a new implementation of a virtual method from the base class in a derived class
Hiding complex implementation details and showing only the essential features of an object
A class that cannot be instantiated and may contain abstract methods that must be implemented by derived classes
A contract that defines a set of methods and properties that implementing classes must provide

Cards.Front: Can a class inherit from multiple classes in C#?
Cards.Back: No, C# only supports single inheritance for classes, but a class can implement multiple interfaces
The member is accessible within its class and by derived classes, but not from outside

Cards.Front: What is a getter and setter?
Cards.Back: Methods that provide controlled access to private fields - getter retrieves the value, setter assigns a new value

Cards.Front: What is the difference between an abstract class and an interface?
Cards.Back: Abstract classes can have implementation and fields; interfaces only define contracts. A class can implement multiple interfaces but inherit from one abstract class

Cards.Front: What is a constructor's purpose in OOP?
Cards.Back: To initialize an object when it is created, setting up initial state and allocating resources

Cards.Front: What is the 'sealed' keyword in C#?
Cards.Back: Prevents a class from being inherited or a method from being overridden further
